ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: We learned about network formation models and estimation techniques.

This was my first proper introductory course on networks. I was exposed to a vast amount of network literature in a systematic manner. The class discussions were extremely fruitful. I also learnt a lot doing the independent class project. The assignments were not too time consuming yet required us to do lot of useful background reading.Overall, I think this course was extremely useful.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: We received a broad overview of networks-related research, so we have a good jumping off point for future research in the area. Some of the ideas were lost on me, however, because the concepts were far beyond my current general understanding of marketing models and techniques (e.g., I have not yet learned about structural estimation for example).
It is too condensed. I think this course can be extended to full semester.

Strengths- Comprehensive syllabus well-compiled for an introductory course in networks.Faculty was highly involved and well-prepared for all sessions. Areas of improvement- We had less time overall, probably it could be a full semester course. There was less time to receive much feedback on our submissions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, but perhaps as a second-year course.
I would highly recommend this course to all management PHD students interested in networks.
